Street Fighter 6 is a very well balanced fighting game with gorgeous graphics and a stylish flair that keeps it fresh for a long time. The mechanics are enjoyable. They've made it accessible to people with poor button skills while high level play is as challenging as for any game. The virtual gaming center (Battle Hub) where you can meet and challenge other players is a great touch.

My one gripe is the World Tour mode. It's cool to be able to make your own avatar and train with all the game characters, but the dialog and cutscenes are terrible. You don't buy this game for the story, and that's a shame considering how much potential this has.  Instead of a couple disconnected quests for each "Master" character they could have given each a full story line and tied that into the world system they created.

Overall, Street Fighter 6 is a great update to the game. It's a great place to start or get back into it if you haven't played a fighting game for a while.
This is my go to fighting game right now. Tournaments are also really fun to watch and analyse. Highly recommend this to all my fellow friends.

World Tour is for the boring people that play a genre that's at it's best when there are two players for the single player. You play as your created character and do busy work grinding for levels and learning the actually cool fighting styles. One glaring issue is that a lot of the mode is catered for modern controls. if you have a move that has one motion input, you cant use another that has the same motion input but a different button. (for example you can't have Hadouken "↓↘→+punch" and Donkey Kick "↓↘→+kick"
Battle Hub is like an avatar lobby. Your created character (either the one from world tour or one you make for battle hub, it depends on which one you open first.) can play on arcade cabinets fighting other players in the lobby, fight using your avatar against others, participate in tournaments, or even play some actual arcade games that shuffle in and out of rotation every once in a while. (proceed with caution, though. some people are super salty and will be super obnoxious in the text chat.)
Fighting Ground is all of the usual stuff you would find in a fighting game. Training, arcade ladders, tutorials, & ranked play. (If you are SUPER new, play ranked. You'll be paired with people on your same level, and you'll have a chance to learn and adjust compared to just getting matched up with whoever.)
The core gameplay is fun, drive as a mechanic is pretty nice, some characters just benefit a little too much from it but that comes with the territory.
Considering that this is still getting updated and I can't see into the future, the meat of the game is worth a try, although I'd say wait until it goes on sale with some (or all if you're reading this like 10 years later) of the DLC.

It's difficult to find a spot to squeeze in with your fighting game thoughs. I feel like I'm too invested to say something that will speak to casual enjoyers, and too much of a scrub to say anything fighting game veterans won't scoff at. The mere fact that I skipped an entire entry in this very series, Street Fighter 5, makes me fundamentally ill equipped to say something like "Street Fighter 6 is the best Street Fighter game, and by extension readily one of the best fighting games of all time."

With that said, I do believe those things are true.

I think there's an X factor in some games that makes them uniquely suited to attracting and encouraging players. There's something about the vibe that is inspiring and uplifting. I'm reminded of how Overwatch felt initially. A design philosophy that inspired every decision with that game was surfacing your progress, highlighting your accomplishments, and tucking away friction like your win/loss ratio. The result was a game that offered a class for every style of play, a position on a team where you could feel like you were contributing, and before you knew it, you were good at the game without experiencing any of the soul sucking mud wrestling with toxic dipshits normally associated with learning a competitive game.

Street Fighter 6, by virtue of being 1v1, transposes those design decisions elsewhere - the prevention of direct communication, the "modern" control option, the various modes through which you ultimately engage with the same aspects of the game with different degrees of friction - but the broader effect is the same. It's a game that is welcoming and excited to have players play it.

And it shows. The pudding is full of proof. Matchmaking keeps queueing you up with opponents in seconds, and no matter your skill or rank, there's an opponent ready to meet you at your level, meaning the player pool is huge and active, three years after launch.

Twist my arm and I would say a weakness is its lack of extra content for normal ranked play. Only twoish extra outfits for each character - if you're lucky and your main has more than one - is pretty wacky when you consider how ready hardcore players are to shell out for a new look after a thousand hours looking at the same character. That aside, even though the pricing is steep, the season passes have delivered character drops that feel *major*. The character choices, Akuma aside, have felt bold and they've been truly exciting to revisit inside the framework of this game. I'm writing this some weeks after C Viper came out (my favourite new character in SF4!), and getting to grips with her is like opening a new game within this game.

I've emphasised the player base and accessibility of the game a lot with this write-up, which may seem strange, but no matter how good the underlying game is, I do consider its popularity its greatest asset. The fact that the environment is there to have such a snappy and fulfilling experience online is simply something most fighting games cannot offer - regardless of the quality of the game itself.

It feels rewarding to love this game, and it's an easy game to love.

The good news about Street Fighter 6 is that there's really something for everyone. The single player content is solid with World Tour and Avatar Battles etc, but if you want to get sweaty on ranked, you can do that to. I have about 600 hours on PS5, plus a couple hundred on PC as of writing this, several characters in master, with my main character sitting comfortably around the 1550MR mark (on a great day), so I can confidently say that I like this game a lot. 

But with most fighting games, there is a caveat, which is that you have to: 

1. Like fighting games 
2. Like the system that the fighting game uses 

SF6 is a modern FGC title through and through, which means that it's easy to learn compared to earlier titles, AND legacy skill is diminished because of it. That doesn't mean if you've been playing Street Fighter since the arcade days that your skills mean nothing, but what it does mean is that there's a lot to learn AND the drive system in this game is very, very strong. 

The best comparison I can think of is through chess. 

Old mainline Street Fighter games were like classic chess -- the speed and timing were just so that while you couldn't take forever, the speed by comparison was much slower.

Modern Street Fighter games are like rapid or blitz chess. It looks similar, but the game is much faster, and you've gotta go fast because the timer is not on your side. 

So it goes with the drive system. There's one way to play. That way to play is really, really fun, but only if it clicks. If it doesn't click, you're going to find that you spend a lot of time on ranked really angry because you died in two hits, and you didn't really get to play the game. 

But, if it does, there is nothing quite like the speed and rapid decision making that goes into a victory, and yes, even the 50/50 emphasis can be enjoyable if you accept the coin toss for what it is, and shift your thinking towards a different game plan than the one you might be expecting. 

Is this game for everyone? It depends on what you want to get out of it. If you're new to Street Fighter and want to learn this classic series, then play this game. If you like aggressive, fast paced gameplay where you can overwhelm your opponent, or make that split second decision that gets you a round, then play this game. If you're hoping for a game more like SFIV or Third Strike, you might be disappointed, but then again, who am I to say otherwise? 

The great days are great, but the bad days are bad -- and unlike older fighting games, you can't grind away forever.

The game is fine, the problem is the company behind. For almost everything you have to pay the MACROtransactions, now even to watch tournaments they want you to pay for it. We are back to the Capcom from the SFxTekken era, but even worst now. 
Fighting Game Community was always about the community trying to promote games, sharing content and knowledge about them, explaining mechanics and different ways to play or learn, that's why we have places like Dustloop, Mizuumi and Supercombo, websites that share countless info about several fighting games, which can be used to help anyone who wants to try a new fighting game (which can be a popular game or a very niche one) or simply learn more about it. There's also several Discord severs with the same purpose, with highly focus on helping players to find a match for them on their favorite fighting games. That together with the rollback netcode was one of the biggest bless we could have in this community. On Youtube you can also get several streamers and channels to watch combo videos, tutorials and tournaments all around the world.
Now, Capcom, the company that is pretty much the biggest one on fighting games (on popularity and in number of players), is going against everything FGC has builded, charging for people to simply watch the tournament.
Compared with the other genres, fighting games aren't that big, but now is bigger than ever before. However, sometimes I wish it was less popular than what it is now, just to avoid these bullshit that companies do when they grow in money and greed.

Keep supporting your locals and the tournaments that people make with their passion, and stop supporting whatever Capcom is trying to throw at you with these abusive prices.
I will keep my negative review until Capcom change their mindset, even knowing that I make no difference on this, but at least I'm doing my part on what I think is right.

Capcom has created a masterpiece of a fighting game with Street Fighter 6, but it's impossible to ignore the elephant in the room: the relentless and predatory monetization. We paid full price for this game, yet Capcom treats it like a free-to-play title, constantly dangling cosmetics and other content behind expensive paywalls. The use of premium, confusingly-priced currencies is a scummy tactic that has no place in a premium game.
The disrespect for the player base reaches a new low when considering the esports side of things. Instead of celebrating the competitive community, Capcom forces fans to pay up to engage with the Capcom Pro Tour and other championship content. It's a blatant cash grab that undermines the very spirit of competitive gaming. The fun gameplay and strong mechanics are overshadowed by a feeling of constantly being nickel-and-dimed. This is a betrayal of consumer trust and a stain on an otherwise excellent game.

As a long-time fan of the series, I wish I could give a neutral rating here on Steam. Unfortunately from my own experience I honestly can't recommend this game in it's current state. I keep trying to like the game, but the more I try, the more I regret my purchase and hours wasted. I purchased the Year 1 Character Pass due to the enthusiasm at launch but they will not get any more money from me for this game until I see some worthwhile game-play tweaks.

This game is not for casuals, myself included. The game is offense heavy and seems tailored to entertain with flashy extended combos. Watching competitive play is OK but actually playing can be rage inducing. 

Graphics, while nice, don't always make a game good and that is definitely what we have here. The input system is downright awful. Character balance is hidden behind the cheaply implemented drive gauge mechanics, boring throw setups, and a stiff input system that favors light attack spams. I spent enough time in training mode looking at frame data at normal and reduced speeds to confirm what I was seeing and feeling during game-play. 

Being pinned in the corner is the worst I have ever felt in a Street Fighter game, and this is going back several games in the series. Some characters have insane corner carry so one whiff punish will have you nearly carried into a corner situation with a huge chunk of your life bar gone.

I suggest anyone interested in the game spend some serious time playing the demo, watching videos, and seeing if you are OK with the feel of the game-play. The 'World Tour' mode was interesting, and helped explained some things, but really won't help you defeat the input system.

2. Practice mode has so many tools that are so useful for learning. You can set up any scenario and practice it over and over. 
3. The net code is really good. 

Now the things I did not enjoy
1. Cheaters and capcoms lackluster response to it is dissapointing and the main reason I am giving a negative review. It ruins the fun of the game, and is just sad. 
2. I am not a fan of the reactive type gameplay loop they have created. Let me explain, in a match I have to react to DI, DR, DRC, Jump in's, and character specific move's. Honestly the elements are fine separately  but together they create a soup of annoyance that I am just not a fan of. A solution in my opinion would be to delete DI, DR, and DRC. That would fix most of the issues for me. 

These two issues are what really bogs this otherwise great game down. But if you enjoy this, have fun but it is not for me I think.
